title: Here’s why Conde Nast Traveler just named Boston one of the best places to go in 2026
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Conde Nast Traveler named Boston a top destination for 2026 due to its rich history and vibrant culture.
Boston will host major events like the 2026 Sail Boston and FIFA World Cup, enhancing its tourist appeal.
New restaurants and diverse neighborhoods like Charlestown and Dorchester are attracting visitors to Boston.

title: Milan Lucic joining AHL’s Springfield Thunderbirds for professional tryout
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Milan Lucic, 37, joins the Springfield Thunderbirds for a professional tryout after his time with the Bruins in 2023.
Lucic previously had a tryout with the St. Louis Blues but was injured in preseason, preventing him from joining the roster.
Drafted by the Bruins in 2006, Lucic has played 1,177 NHL games, scoring 586 points and amassing 1,301 penalty minutes.

title: Seth Meyers responds after Trump calls him a ‘deranged lunatic’ for ‘probably illegal’ late-night jokes
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Seth Meyers responded to Donald Trump's Truth Social post calling him a 'deranged lunatic' for mocking catapult discussions.
The conflict arose from an October 30th segment where Meyers mocked Trump's focus on catapults in an October 28 speech.
Trump has criticized Meyers before, questioning NBC's decision to extend his contract and labeling him untalented.

title: Police investigate apparent murder-suicide in Beverly
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Police found two people dead from gunshot wounds in a Beverly home on Colonial Drive Monday night.
The incident is being investigated as an apparent murder-suicide with no threat to the public.
Authorities are withholding the identities of the deceased pending notification of next of kin.

title: Canton police sergeant involved in Karen Read case placed on leave over alleged misconduct
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Canton Police Sgt. Sean Goode placed on paid leave amid misconduct allegations, pending an internal investigation.
Allegations against Goode arose during a probe into a former member of another law enforcement agency.
Karen Read's case, where Goode testified, ended with her acquittal on murder and manslaughter charges.

title: It’s the end of the line for Hubba Hubba in Cambridge
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Hubba Hubba, an adult store in Cambridge, is closing on November 24 after 47 years due to financial difficulties.
Owner M.J. Pullins cited rising costs, landlord issues, and economic challenges as reasons for ceasing operations.
Store's closure affects the alternative and LGBTQ+ community, having served them with a unique product range since 1978.

title: ‘Unacceptable’: What Jaylen Brown, NBA official had to say about controversial moment in Celtics’ loss
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Celtics lost to the Jazz 105-103 at home after squandering a second-half lead.
Jaylen Brown criticized officiating for not calling a foul when he appeared tripped in the final minute.
NBA referee Kevin Scott said no foul was called as both players were seen slipping before any contact.

title: Moving to Massachusetts isn’t easy — when did you finally feel at home?
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Hayley Perry-Sanchez moved to Cambridge with her husband for his Harvard MBA program, facing a tough adjustment.
Perry-Sanchez struggled with weather, transportation, and isolation in Boston, relying heavily on student loans.
Finding community at a local craft store in Dorchester helped Perry-Sanchez feel more connected to Massachusetts.

title: Parts of Morrissey Blvd. may close this week due to high tide flooding
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Parts of Morrissey Boulevard may close due to high tide flooding between Tuesday and Sunday.
Closures expected from Freeport Street to Bianculli Boulevard; police may close the I-93 off ramp if needed.
High tides predicted to reach around 12 feet once daily from Nov. 4 to Nov. 9, according to DCR.

title: Voting guide: Here’s what voters need to know before Boston’s Tuesday election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Polls will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. at 275 voting precincts in Boston for the municipal election.
Mayor Michelle Wu is running unopposed, but several Boston City Council at-large and district seats are contested.
Voters can return mail ballots to 22 drop boxes or City Hall by 8 p.m. Tuesday, not at polling places.
